results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Fiji, New Caledonia and New Zealand, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film shows a cruise from Sydney Harbour to possibly New Caledonia, Fiji and New Zealand, including scenic views, time with friends’ son and off the cruise ship.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:34:00 leaving Sydney Harbour in cruise ship; views of the Opera House and the Harbour
00:01:36:00 views from lookout wth friends, looking over a small city
00:04:27:00 a day trip from cruise to island, maybe New Caledonia, due to circular style of grass hut
00:05:26:00 ring volleyball game on cruise ship
00:06:43:00 views from cruise ship coming into port at Nadi, Fiji
00:08:26:00 filmmaker’s wife Evelyn with local family, and swimming at the beach
00:10:08:00 cruise ship coming into port, marching band farewells/welcomes passengers
00:11:50:00 Rainbow Springs sign, Rotorua, NZ
00:12:06:00 trout farm at Rainbow Springs Nature Park
00:13:42:00 hot springs in New Zealand
0014:27:00 cruise ship coming back into Sydney harbour, views of cliffs surrounding Sydney Harbour

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Hong Kong, Japan, Singapore and Thailand, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film captures a trip to Southeast Asia including Hong Kong, Japan, possibly Thailand and Singapore, including cruising around bays, along rivers, scenic views, traditional dance, temple visits and a visit to Kranji War Cemetery, Singapore.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:34:00 Australian Naval Ship in the bay, most likely Hong Kong
00:01:13:00 young boys in small wooden boats appear to be almost knocked over by the ferry or cruise ship the filmmaker is on
00:03:57:00 Shining Star Ferry in Hong Kong
00:04:51:00 plane to Japan
00:07:05:00 a trip to a waterfall, filmmaker’s wife and friends with Japanese friend or tour guide
00:07:53:00 scenic views of possibly Osaka
00:09:17:00 train station, possibly Kansai Station; we see a Kansai Paints billboard behind train
00:10:09:00 a visit to temples surrounded by cherry blossom, perhaps in Kyoto
00:11:10:00 ice skating perhaps in a function centre, skaters dressed in Scottish dress, then Russian, then cowboys
00:13:08:00 possibly views from an airport, a carpark surrounded by mountains, possibly Thailand, as short street views have writing in what appears to be Thai
00:13:35:00 a cruise along a river, markets of people selling food and people living in small houses along the river surrounded by forest and jungle
00:15:40:00 traditional dancers performing and elephant performing tasks for an audience
00:17:05:00 more traditional dancing
00:17:42:00 we see a sign for Kanji War Cemetery, Singapore, a short trip to the memorial
00:18:30:00 snake charmers in a city mall
00:19:22:00 feeding monkeys in a park
00:20:17:00 exotic planet and orchid display
00:21:04:00 possibly back in Australia; a car and boat parade with some of the cars flying the Australian flag

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film shows a trip to Israel including visits to Jerusalem before the wall was constructed and various religious sites, such as the Wailing Wall, King David’s Tomb, Lazarus Tomb.

Selected HIghlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:52:00 the Wailing Wall, Jerusalem, also known as the Buraq Wall in Islamic
00:01:01:00 Mount of Olives, Chapel of Assencion
00:03:20:00 King David’s Tomb
00:04:25:00 Manger Square
00:09:17:00 local children with animals and tents
00:09:39:00 Beth’ Shearim Catacombs outside the entrance
00:09:59:00 Megiddo City, featuring the city water system, swimming pool
00:10:59:00 Belvouir Castle remains from 12th Century
00:12:22:00 Rosh Hanikra cable car alongside chalk cliffs overlooking the Mediterranean Sea
00:14:42:00 Capharaum – the Town of Jesus, city and scenic views
00:15:36:00 border crossing, family and friends posing with Israel military
00:16:51:00 waterfalls
00:017:05:00 the Good Fence and Temple of Augustus
00:18:34:00 houses in side of mountains
00:19:47:00 high country, stone houses in amongst stone hills with incredible sunsets
00:20:32:00 Lazarus Tomb and Inn of the Good Samaritan

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Papua New Guinea and United States, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film shows a trip to the USA and Australia. It includes footage of the World Trade Centre twin towers and the Statue of Liberty in NYC, Disneyland, Pearl Harbour in Hawaii, Puffing Billy in Melbourne, views of Sydney Harbour, and a snippet back in New Guinea.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:15:00 group of friends of filmmaker gather at a pier
00:02:00:00 view of Twin Towers and the Statue of Liberty from a ferry
00:05:00:00 Red Rocks Amphitheatre in Colorado
00:11:28:00 a visit to Disneyland and a zoo
00:15:53:00 a visit to Pearl Harbour, USS Arizona Memorial in Honolulu, Hawaii, with views from a ferry and of local resort
00:18:45:00 friends with a baby in the Dandenong Ranges, featuring Puffing Billy in Emerald
00:19:54:00 views of Sydney Harbour, Opera House, Harbour Bridge from a high level of a hotel
00:20:14:00 long lost children’s playground featuring UFO style fizzy dizzy’s and sides and seesaws
00:20:22:00 back to New Guinea, a celebration or demonstration

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This home movie is shot in New Guinea. It includes scenic views over the bay (possibly Mapang), traditional dress, dance and reenactments, and a gathering and BBQ at the Faith Mission in Lufa.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:36:00 scenic view over the bay in Port Moresby, car in shot has ‘Mapang Missionary Home’ written on side
00:04:34:00 gathering of people wearing traditional dress from various districts
00:06:25:00 celebrations begin with parachuters landing from above into middle of football field
00:07:14:00 in traditional dress, people gather, reenactment of fighting, and dancing
00:10:33:00 ‘Faith Mission Hairo’ sign in Lufa, a BBQ and gathering of people including Evelyn Sinclair
00:12:33:00 another gathering at S.I.L. (Summer Institute for Linguistics) in Ukarumpa

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Netherlands, Switzerland and Wales, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film depicts a trip to the Netherlands and Switzerland, beginning in Welshpool, Wales. It features scenes of “The Dingle” gardens, country fairs, folk dancing, show jumping in Welshpool, Dutch seaside, canal trips in the Netherlands, streetscapes, countryside, farm life, Rotterdam, Spannenburg, bus trip to the Alps, Switzerland, Brienz and Grindenwald.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:40:00 sign “The Dingle” of the Dingle Gardens
00:01:14:00 folk dancing at a country fair
00:02:10:00 horse jumping
00:02:51:00 Dutch seaside featuring people in lounge chairs
00:03:15:00 canal trip through countryside and urban area
00:04:11:00 farm life and creatures including a white peacock, and a young adult in fashionable clothing and clogs holding a skull
00:05:55:00 Commonwealth War Grave sign and cemetery
00:06:05:00 Spannenburg sign shot from a car
00:06:30:00 De Dude Are Museum sign and building shot from boat on a canal
00:07:29:00 in city, people gathering for the arrival of a celebrity
00:07:46:00 three people lining up to eat fish by holding tail up in the air above their heads, in sync
00:07:52:00 miniature theme park featuring tiny windmills, trams, boats, gardens, with one of the boats on fire
00:11:46:00 local market in Rotterdam, possibly; youth fashion
00:14:03:00 bus trip to Switzerland, featuring mountains and countryside scenes
00:16:02:00 feeding bears in a zoo
00:18:09:00 scene of large waterfall
00:20:13:00 Sinclair’s friends having a snowball fight
00:20:58:00 steam train

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This home movie shows the filmmaker and his wife travelling around England in a small yellow mini. They begin in London and travel across England to Stonehenge, up through the south of Scotland up to Loch Lomond and The Trossachs National Park, back to Edinburgh and end up in Blackpool.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:02:47:00 changing of the Guard
00:05:23:00 Stonehenge – brief look at Stonehenge
00:05:34:00 Stratford-Upon-Avon Cricket Club sign, walking through gardens and a spot of cricket
00:06:58:00 Shakespeare’s Birthplace Trust
00:09:17:00 road trip sign to Penrith, Carlisle and Kendal
00:10:17:00 Fferry trip – Windemere ferry, ’The Ferry House Windemere Laboratory of the Freshwater Biological Association Private Gardens’
00:13:15:00 Loch Lomond Sailings Ltd
00:14:42:00 the Elizabethan Inn – filmmaker and wife meet up with three other women at the inn
00:15:39:00 Tormore Distillery with friends – Long John Scotch Whiskey
00:16:56:00 father and two young girls feeding ducks at a lake
00:17:41:00 Roths Glen Hotel – mini donkeys and friends
00:19:11:00 sign to Pitlochry
00:19:45:00 castle or Military Fort in Edinburgh, guards in kilts
00:20:17:00 cemetery for soldier dogs
00:21:14:00 Blackpool

results.title: Centripetal Forces
results.credit_line:
Shaun Gladwell
Eight-channel video installation, variable duration
ACMI Collection
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, 8 channel video, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
“Centripetal Forces” is an eight-channel video installation commissioned for the exhibition “Shaun Gladwell: Stereo Sequences” in 2011.

“Centripetal Forces” (2011) is an elaboration of Gladwell’s interest in the dynamics and composition of the spinning figure, first seen in the single-channel “Pataphysical Man” (2005). “Centripetal Forces” takes the original image of the spinning figure and extends it into a series of comparative studies of gesture and movement by different performers. In the centre of each screen a performer enacts a basic spinning action over and over, each dancer representing a different language or subculture of movement.

Gladwell further pushes this internal paradox with a shift in perspective from the original work, changing the camera viewpoint from a front-on to an aerial view. The black and white negative images are projected on to screens suspended in the ceiling of the gallery, appearing as spinning astral bodies – a sparkling universe of whirling figures. There is a clear connection here to the “Planet & Stars Sequence” and to”‘Parallel Forces”. Are these bodies orbiting each other? Are they aware of their relationship to a wider planetary system? Are they stationary or are they turning on a still point?

The performers are training rather than performing; their focus is on repetition and rotation of movements. There is Emma Magenta, a capoeira dancer, whose roughly circular movements recall her performance in “Woolloomooloo Night” (2004). Her movements are more muscular and less centred than the tight, graceful, fluid pirouettes of Vivienne Wong, ballerina with the Australian Ballet. Anthony Lawang, a break dancer from Melbourne, performs a series of floor-based manoeuvres, transitioning from a top rock position to a backspin and a windmill, climaxing in a tight backspin, disrupting any sense of how his body is oriented spatially. Simon O’Brien, a world champion freestyle BMX rider, performs a series of highly technical spins in which the bike frame and his body are linked and twisted by concentric forces. In contrast to these athletic routines, Kathryn Puie spins her body on stilts. In the overhead shot foreshortening her body, we see her body constantly shifting and shuffling in order to remain upright. Gladwell himself performs on a skateboard, spinning continuously. Contemporary dancer Lee Wilson uses his body as the pivot point for a whirling bread tray that flies above and around him. Michelle Shimmy and Maddie Schonstein, professional pole dancers, perform an improvised routine together on a pole, experimenting with movements and pushing their bodies into unrehearsed positions.

results.title: Track and Trials
results.credit_line:
Shaun Gladwell
Dual-channel video installation
ACMI Collection
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, 2 channel video, projection, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
“Track and Trials” is a dual-channel video installation commissioned for the exhibition “Shaun Gladwell: Stereo Sequences” in 2011.

The two-channel installation “Track and Trials” sets up a relationship between two opposing screens. One features footage of track riding under the Sydney Harbour Bridge (track riding is a fixed, single gear, break-less style of bicycle riding that was developed in the velodrome but made popular by couriers in New York City in the late 1990s). The second features trials bike riding (a competitive off-road, all-terrain practice that also uses fixed gear bicycles) on a rocky ocean foreshore.

Both trials and track riders stall their bicycles, often making themselves completely still. Gladwell is attracted to the contradiction between the potential speed of these bicycles and their capacity for stasis and perfect poise – the push and pull of these opposing forces. The Track screen references Grace Cossington-Smith’s painting “The Bridge in Curve” (1926), the Sydney Harbour Bridge near completion. Cossington-Smith celebrates not only the construction of the bridge as a triumph of engineering but also Australian modernism. Gladwell replicates Cossington-Smith’s perspective while celebrating the ways in which the riders have reclaimed the space underneath the bridge as a space for creativity, beyond the intended functionality of the space.

Similarly, the Trials screen references Caspar David Friedrich’s romantic painting “Wanderer Above the Sea of Fog” (1818), in which a man standing on a rocky outcrop looks out onto a stormy ocean. Like Friedrich’s subject, the trials rider is ‘wedged between two time signatures – the slow geological signature of the rocks and the furious swell of the ocean’, as Gladwell describes it. As the rider reaches the top of the rocks he rests, putting his feet to the ground, and takes in the view of the ocean from a vantage point he has worked hard to achieve. Like Friedrich’s wanderer, Gladwell’s rider is insignificant within a landscape while striving for mastery over it.
